courseTitle: Simulating Methods to Estimate Population Size

pageData.titleName2: Simulating Methods to Estimate Population Size

pageData.text: In this set of activities, three different sampling techniques will be used to estimate <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button>: <button class='glossary-text'>transects</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>mark and recapture</button>. Multiple trials for each method will be conducted, and population cover, <button class='glossary-text'>density</button>, and size will be estimated using algebra and graphing skills.

Small bowl

Calculator

pageData.title: Time Requirements

Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: A. Estimating Population Cover—Transects - 30 minutes
Activity 1: B. Estimating Population Density— Quadrats - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Estimating Population Size—Mark and Recapture - 30 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: A. Estimating Population Cover—Transects - 30 minutes
Activity 1: B. Estimating Population Density— Quadrats - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Estimating Population Size—Mark and Recapture - 30 minutes

pageData.text: The activities can be completed in any order. The lab can be paused after completing any of the activities.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Simulating Methods to Estimate Population Size

text: Demonstrate methodologies used by scientists to estimate the <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button> of various organisms.
Conduct investigations using multiple trials to collect and analyze data.
Use algebra and graphing skills to estimate population sizes.
Discuss some of the limitations of selected population sampling techniques.
Determine which sampling technique works best for a particular organism.

pageData.text: Studying organisms in the wild is a challenging endeavor. Biologist Walter Auffenberg observed Komodo Dragons in the field for a year, and later published the idea that the Komodo Dragon kills its prey with the help of pathogenic bacteria, allowing it to take down large animals like water buffalo. Auffenberg supposed that when a Komodo Dragon attacks its prey, pathogenic bacteria from the dragon’s saliva enter the prey’s wounds and, after a few days, bacterial toxins kill the prey. Despite its lack of scientific evidence, this hypothesis was taught as truth for decades.

Bryan Fry from the University of Queensland finally disproved the myth about Komodo Dragons’ killer saliva in 2009 when he put a Komodo Dragon in a medical scanner and discovered it had venom glands<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. The glands are filled with a toxic venom that lowers blood pressure, causes massive bleeding, prevents clotting, and induces shock. Fry suggested that the dragons kill by using their serrated teeth to bite down hard and then pull back with their strong neck muscles. This action results in large gaping wounds by which the venom can enter the bloodstream, thus increasing the loss of blood and causing the prey to go into shock. Although extensive studies have been performed on Komodo Dragon bacteria, no venom-producing bacteria have ever been identified.
1Yong, E. (2013, June 27). The Myth of the Komodo Dragon's Dirty Mouth. National Geographic. https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/the-myth-of-the-komodo-dragons-dirty-mouth

pageData.desc: A large Komodo dragon sticking out its forked tongue.
pageData.altText: A large Komodo dragon sticking out its forked tongue.

pageData.text: Hunting and fishing limits often indicate the number, size, or type of organism that can be removed from a population during a specific time of year. These limits often vary year-to-year depending on the condition of the population in question. Hunting and fishing limits are based upon the results of studies conducted to determine the size of target organism populations.

The importance of <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button> also becomes apparent through discussions of endangered species such as the giant panda, the Queen Alexandra’s Birdwing butterfly, or the dragon tree. Often, discussions regarding endangered species are accompanied by numbers indicating how many individual members of that species are left in the wild. These numbers are determined through population counts. How are populations counted? Certainly all the organisms do not line up in orderly rows and allow scientists to count them, so what is it that scientists do to determine the size of an animal or plant population?

When subjects are <button class='glossary-text'>sessile</button> (unmoving), like plants and trees, researchers plot squares (called <button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button>) or straight lines (called <button class='glossary-text'>transects</button>) in areas that most accurately represents the target population. A critical part of these studies is making sure the quadrats and transects accurately represent a true sampling of the area. In contrast, zoologists study populations of animals that can move or hide; this can make determining the size of a population more difficult. Aside from locomotion, animals also exhibit other behaviors that can make population counting difficult, such as <button class='glossary-text'>schooling</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>herding</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>flocking</button>. The most straightforward method of determining the size of an animal population is the direct count, but this is rarely practical except in small, contained habitats. As with plants, population estimates for relatively easy-to-spot animals, such as birds and fish, can also be based on counts from sampling transects or quadrats. These counts yield <button class='glossary-text'>population indices</button> or trends that enable researchers to recognize significant population changes over time.

Scientists have developed other sampling techniques that are grounded in statistics. One such method involves capturing and marking a small number of individuals within a population. Recording the number of marked individuals that are subsequently recaptured gives scientists an idea of the size of the population. Another method, called <button class='glossary-text'>removal sampling</button>, involves removing captured individuals from the population. After several capture-and-removal trials, the number of individuals captured will decrease, which enables scientists to estimate the original size of the population.

The above-mentioned sampling techniques can be varied depending on the organism being sampled. Sampling data can also be presented and interpreted in different ways. For instance, a forester might want to know the percent coverage of each type of tree in a forest; an ichthyologist might want to track the actual number of bass in a lake; and an ecologist might want to monitor trends in the <button class='glossary-text'>density</button> of an invasive plant species.

pageData.question: A critical part of population studies is making sure the quadrats or transects used accurately represent a true sampling of the area. Which of the following complicates these sampling techniques?

options.text: the population’s movement and social behaviors
contamination of the sampling area by pollution
human error in making perfectly equal plots

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Zoologists study populations of animals that can move or hide, as well as exhibit other behaviors such as schooling, herding, or flocking; this can make determining the size of a population more difficult.

pageData.question: Which of the following populations is most likely to be the easiest to count?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Sessile organisms, like plants, are easier to count because they do not move from location to location.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: When subjects are sessile, researchers can easily plot quadrats or transects in areas that most accurately represent the target population. Sessile organisms do have the ability to move actively. The most straightforward method of determining the size of an animal population is the direct count, but this is rarely practical except in small, contained habitats. As with plants, population estimates for relatively easy-to-spot animals, such as birds and fish, can also be based on counts from sampling transects or quadrats. Unlike plants, animals exhibit behaviors such as locomotion (moving or hiding), schooling, herding, and flocking; these can make determining the size of a population more difficult.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: When subjects are sessile, researchers can easily plot quadrats or transects in areas that most accurately represent the target population. Sessile organisms do have the ability to move actively. The most straightforward method of determining the size of an animal population is the direct count, but this is rarely practical except in small, contained habitats. As with plants, population estimates for relatively easy-to-spot animals, such as birds and fish, can also be based on counts from sampling transects or quadrats. Unlike plants, animals exhibit behaviors such as locomotion (moving or hiding), schooling, herding, and flocking; these can make determining the size of a population more difficult.

pageData.subTitle: Transects
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Transects</button> can be used to estimate <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>density</button>, and diversity within a habitat. This common sampling technique is based on the statistical principle that the average population size observed along a transect is proportional to the size of the total population in the habitat. This type of sampling allows for data collection over a larger range of the habitat being studied compared to other sampling methodologies.

Perhaps the most common method of using transects involves running multiple transect lines randomly throughout the habitat under study. At set distances along each transect, an observer records the number of target organisms at each point. After data from several transects have been gathered, the numbers are compiled and averaged, and the results are extrapolated to apply to the entire study area.

pageData.subTitle: Quadrats
pageData.text: Population size, density, and diversity within a habitat can also be estimated using <button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button>. This common sampling technique is based on the statistical principle that the average number of target organisms in <button class='glossary-text'>subpopulations</button> within quadrats is proportional to the total population of the habitat. For example, if each 1 m<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup> quadrat contains an average of 10 individuals of a given species, then an area that is 1 km<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup> (1,000 m<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>) should contain approximately 10,000 individuals.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Scientists observing square quadrats layed out on a rocky beach.

pageData.text: In practice, <button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button> usually measure 0.5 m<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>or 1 m<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>, although they may be any size. Researchers place quadrats randomly throughout the test site and then inventory what they find in each. A key to this sampling technique is the placement of quadrats throughout the habitat. If an external condition creates a bias in quadrat placement (e.g., conditions result in the placement of quadrats where there seems to be a higher concentration of the target species), the subsequent statistical analyses will be inaccurate.

pageData.subTitle: Mark and Recapture
pageData.text: Scientists can also estimate <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button> using the <button class='glossary-text'>mark and recapture</button> method. In this method, the population is sampled by first capturing, tagging, and then releasing a number of individuals back into the environment. After sufficient time has passed to allow the animals to redistribute, another random sample is captured. Some of the captured individuals will likely be marked and some will not. From the percentage of marked individuals in the recapture and the original number of individuals marked, one can calculate the approximate size of the population (Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: There is a hypothetical population of green birds, size is unknown (N). The first survey of 5 individuals is taken from the population and marked with a dot.  Marked individuals are returned to the original population and allowed to mix with the unmarked members. A second sample is taken, and 6 individuals are captured (C equals 6) and 2 are recaptured (R equals 2). The equation to find the unknown population of green birds is N approximately equals M times C divided by R. The population is approximately 15.

pageData.question: Maggie used a sampling method to estimate the population of a group of birds. In her first survey, she captured 5 birds and marked them. She returned them to the original population and after a few weeks, she took a second survey and caught 6 individuals, of which 2 had been marked. What technique did Maggie use to estimate the population of the birds?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In the mark and recapture method, the population is sampled by first capturing, tagging, and then releasing several individuals back into the environment. After sufficient time has passed to allow the animals to redistribute, another random sample is captured.

pageData.question: Reggie used a sampling method to estimate the population of a group of birds. In his first survey, he captured 5 birds and marked them. He returned them to the original population and after a few weeks, he took a second survey and caught 6 individuals, of which 2 had been marked. Based on his collected data, what would Reggie estimate the population of the birds to be?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: N = MC /RNumber of individuals in population = original number marked x average number captured /average number of marked individuals recapturedN = 5 x 6 /2N = 15

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Scientists can estimate population size using the mark and recapture method. In this method, the population is sampled by first capturing, tagging, and then releasing several individuals back into the environment. After sufficient time has passed to allow the animals to redistribute, another random sample is captured. In this second survey, some of the captured individuals will likely be marked and some will not. From the percentage of marked individuals in the recapture and the original number of individuals marked, one can calculate the approximate size of the population.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, draw transects on the population sheet and count the color of the squares touching the transects at each interval. Then, calculate the number of squares of each color and the percentage coverage of each color. Next, make a quadrat out of a chenille stem and place it on the population sheet. Count the red and green squares in the quadrat, repeating this step for 5 different quadrat placements. Finally, calculate the density of each color. In Activity 2, place the white beads in a bowl and replace some of the white beads with red beads to indicate a marked subpopulation. Then, capture a sample of beads and calculate the percentage of marked beads in the sample. Repeat the capturing steps until 20 samples have been captured. Then, calculate the average percentage of marked beads in a sample. Finally, estimate the population size of the white beads.

Count the red and green squares in the quadrat, repeating this step for 5 different quadrat placements. Finally, calculate the density of each color. In Activity 2, place the white beads in a bowl and replace some of the white beads with red beads to indicate a marked subpopulation. Then, capture a sample of beads and calculate the percentage of marked beads in the sample. Repeat the capturing steps until 20 samples have been captured. Then, calculate the average percentage of marked beads in a sample. Finally, estimate the population size of the white beads.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Population estimation methods, including transects, quadrats, and mark and recapture, are based on the same underlying assumption.  What is that assumption?

options.text: The sample collected is representative of the entire population.
It is more important to count animals than plants.
The method will enable counting of all the organisms in the study area.
The number of organisms is more important than their diversity.
Animals move around and are difficult to count.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following groups best demonstrates a population?

options.text: all the beavers that were living along the Green River in 2022
all the hummingbirds in a backyard and the flowers from which they feed
all the tadpoles of all the frog species in the United States
all the wetlands inhabited by mangrove trees
all the petals produced by cherry trees from 1990-1999

assestmentData.question: A landowner wants to estimate the number of old growth trees to evaluate the worth of a parcel of land they wish to lease to loggers.  Which sampling method should they use?
What type of safety hazard is associated with this investigation?

options.text: The beads are a choking hazard.
The chenille stem is a flammable material.
The chemicals provided are corrosive materials.
Chlorine bleach gives off toxic fumes.

assestmentData.question: What material is needed but not supplied for you in the materials kit for this lab?

A student is given the task of estimating how many daffodils are in a two-acre piece of woodland. She places three random 1 square-meter (m2) quadrats and counts an average of five plants per quadrat. How many daffodils can she estimate are in the two-acre plot?1 acre = 4046.86 m2
State authorities want to estimate the size of a population of fish so they can set catch limits. Which sampling method should they use?
Researchers want to estimate the percent coverage of an invasive grass species to determine how much danger is posed to local populations.  Which sampling method should they use?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

In Activity 1, you will estimate the population of a simulated species by using <button class='glossary-text'>transect</button> lines to estimate the area covered by the population. You will then estimate the <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button> using <button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button> to measure the population size in a subsection of the area, then multiplying that number by the total area.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, <button class='glossary-text'>transect</button> lines will be used to determine the percent coverage of each of the three colors on the population sheet. This process could also be used to determine the population <button class='glossary-text'>density</button> of one of the colors or even the diversity of colors on the sheet.

pageData.text: For this activity you will need: population sheet, ruler, wet-erase marker, calculator, and a damp towel or tissue for eraser.

Using the ruler and marker, make five 10-cm lines, or transects, on the population sheet.
Note: Each line should be randomly placed on the sheet and can be drawn in any direction. All lines must be completely within the colored portion of the sheet.
Draw a small dot every 0.5 cm along each transect.
Find the 0.0-cm starting point of the first transect drawn and note the color of the square the transect line is touching.
Record the color of the square in Data Table 1 on the data sheet (Transect 1, 0.0 cm).
Move along the transect line toward the endpoint. At every 0.5-cm interval, determine what color square the transect line is touching.

Record the color for each of these points in Data Table 1.
Note: In some cases it may be difficult to determine which square the transect line is touching; be consistent in using the same criterion to decide which square the line is touching.
Repeat this process for the other four transects so that there are five complete data sets.

Count the total number of squares of each color as recorded in Data Table 1. In Data Table 2, record the total number of red, blue, and green squares that were touching the transect lines, as well as the total number of squares counted.
For each color, determine the percent cover by dividing the total number of squares of that color by the total number of squares counted. Record the percent cover values in Data Table 2.
Clean off the population sheet with a damp cloth.
Repeat this activity to determine the reproducibility of the data collection.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Estimating Population Density— Quadrats (9 steps)

typeBefore.text: In this activity, <button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button> will be used to determine the density of red squares and green squares. For this activity, blue will represent open space. After the density per quadrat is determined, the <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button> for a given area can be estimated. Data obtained from the quadrats could also be used to determine the percent coverage and the diversity of each color on the population sheet.

pageData.text: For this activity you will need: population sheet, scissors, chenille stem, clear tape, a ruler, and a calculator.

Make a 6.25-cm2 quadrat using the chenille stem.
  1. From one end of the stem, measure 3.0 cm and then bend the stem at a right angle.
  2. Continue another 3.0 cm along the stem and then cut the stem with scissors. Measure and bend the other piece of stem in the same way indicated in step a.
  3. Overlap the bent stems to create a square with ends that overlap one another by 0.5 cm.
  4. Bend the overlapping ends over one another to secure the stems in the shape of a square, as shown below. The square should measure 2.5 cm × 2.5 cm. See Figure 3.

pageData.desc: Demonstrating how to cut, bend, and twist the pipe cleaner to make a quadrat.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Demonstrating how to cut, bend, and twist the pipe cleaner to make a quadrat.

pageData.text: The red and green squares on the population sheet each represent a different species (two species in all). Randomly place the quadrat on a section of the population sheet. Use clear tape to secure the quadrat to the sheet.
Count the number of red squares and the number of green squares inside the quadrat.

It may be difficult to tell whether some squares close to the edge of the quadrat are inside or outside. Develop a criterion to either include or exclude these squares from the data. For example, always count the squares that are fully inside the quadrat and not touching the chenille stem.
Record the number of red squares and the number of green squares in Data Table 3. Remove the quadrat from the population sheet.

Repeat this process four times, each time at a different randomly determined location on the population sheet.
Note: For each count, be sure to use the same criterion for determining whether border squares are inside or outside the quadrat.
Collect a total of five data sets and then determine the total number of squares of each color for all five quadrats combined. Record this information in Data Table 3.

Calculate the average density of red and green squares per 6.25 cm2 by dividing the total number of squares of each color (from all quadrats) by the total number of quadrats, which is 5. Record this information in Data Table 3.
Calculate the density per cm2 by dividing the average density of red and green squares by the area of one quadrat, which in this case is 6.25 cm2. Record this information in Data Table 3.

In Activity 2, you will estimate the <button class='glossary-text'>population size</button> of a simulated population by marking a subset of the population, releasing it back to the environment, and then recapturing a sample. You will then use the ratio of marked to total individuals in the sample to estimate the overall population.

pages.title: Estimating Population Size— Mark and Recapture (13 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Estimating Population Size— Mark and Recapture (13 steps)

typeBefore.text: In this activity, the <button class='glossary-text'>mark and recapture</button> method is simulated to determine the size of a population. The beads in the bowl represent a population of organisms found in a research area. White beads represent the untagged population and colored beads represent captured and marked individuals from the original population being returned to their environment.

pageData.text: For this activity you will need: white beads, colored beads, 2 cups, a bowl, and a calculator.
Transfer all of the white beads in the cup to the bowl.
Remove a small handful (10–25) of white beads from the bowl. This represents a captured portion of the untagged population.
Count the white beads that were captured; put them in the now empty small cup and then set the cup aside.
Count out a number of colored beads equivalent to the number of white beads that were removed from the bowl.
Place the colored beads in the bowl containing the original population of white beads. These colored beads now represent ‘marked individuals.’
In Data Table 4, record the number of colored beads (marked individuals) that are now in the population.

Randomly capture (i.e., remove) another handful of beads (25–40) from the bowl. This is Sample 1. In Data Table 4, record the total number of beads in the sample that was captured. Next, count and record the number of marked beads that were recaptured.
Calculate the percentage of the sample made up of individuals that were marked and recaptured. Record the results in Data Table 4.
Return the beads to the bowl.
Repeat steps 8, 9, and 10 until 20 samples have been captured.
Determine the average percentage of the sample that was marked and recaptured for all 20 samples.

Estimate the (see Equation 1). First, multiply the original number of marked individuals by the average number of individuals captured. Next, divide that number by the average number of marked individuals recaptured. This is the population size. Record the population size in Data Table 4.

pageData.desc: original number marked × average number captured over average number of marked individuals recaptured = estimated population size
pageData.altText: Equation 1: original number marked × average number captured over average number of marked individuals recaptured = estimated population size

Then, calculate the number of squares of each color and the percentage coverage of each color. Next, make a quadrat out of a chenille stem and place it on the population sheet. Equation 1: original number marked × average number captured over average number of marked individuals recaptured = estimated population size

data.title: Density
data.content: Referring to population density; the concentration of individuals within a species in a specific geographic locale

data.title: Flocking
data.content: The assembling of a group of animals (such as birds or sheep)

data.title: Herding
data.content: The social grouping of certain animals of the same species

data.title: Mark and recapture
data.content: A technique used to estimate the size of a population in situations where it is impractical to count every individual

data.title: Population indices
data.content: A mathematical description of changes in a population over time; singular, population index

data.title: Population size
data.content: Number of individual organisms in a population

data.title: Quadrat
data.content: A frame, traditionally square, used to isolate a standard unit of area for study of the distribution of an item over a large area

data.title: Removal sampling
data.content: The technique of repeated sampling of a population and removing the individuals from that population

data.title: Schooling
data.content: The swimming together of a group of aquatic animals in the same direction in a coordinated manner

data.title: Sessile
data.content: To be unable to move actively

data.title: Transect
data.content: A straight line that cuts through a natural landscape so that standardized observations and measurements can be made
